instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Got one more of these old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards. I have all main power rails and I have [FONT=Courier]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>. When pressing power I only get 0,78V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> should be 3.3 I think.

There is no short to ground and all the enable resistors and capacitors on this line is fine.

Is this bad SMC? [/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That is ok. Voltage before and after <RESISTOR>R7859</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Both sides the same 0.106, which is what I get everywhere i measure <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> when i press the power button. It raised from 0 to 0.1V when button is pressed. One more thing i wrote the wrong value i the first post it should be 0.078-0.1V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Are you using a 85W charger?  <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="XooP, post: 2209"]Yes, a genuine Apple 85W charger, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> =3.39V[/QUOTE]

Im writing from a mac with that board right now, and it uses a 60W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Shouldn't matter if the charger can handle more than 60W. If I was using a 45W charger, then it could be an issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No! 15" board will NOT power on from anything else than an 85W charger!

I have no more ideas about this one really, any history on this board, water?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You know this is a 13 inch board? And yes it was as originally water damaged

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Well, I'll try to reflow the SMC before it goes into the donor bin :)
